week.title: Temptation & Fall
week.memoryVerse: In him we have redemption through his blood, the forgiveness of our trespasses. (Ephesians 1:7)

days.title: Who Tempted Them to This Sin?

catechism.question: Who tempted them to this sin?
catechism.answer: The devil tempted Eve, and she gave the fruit to Adam.

content: In the beautiful garden where everything was perfect, a terrible visitor arrived. This visitor was Satan, also called the devil, who had once been a beautiful angel but chose to rebel against God. He was filled with hatred for God and wanted to destroy Adam and Eve's wonderful relationship with their Creator.

Satan was very clever and sneaky. He didn't appear as a scary monster that would frighten them. Instead, he disguised himself as a serpent and spoke to Eve when she was near the forbidden tree. He made himself seem friendly and helpful, but his heart was full of lies.

Satan began by questioning what God had said: 'Did God really say you must not eat from every tree in the garden?' He was trying to make Eve doubt God's clear command. Then he told her a bold lie: 'You will not surely die. You will be like God.'

Eve listened to Satan's lies instead of remembering God's loving warning. She looked at the fruit and decided it looked good to eat. So she took some and ate it. But she didn't sin alone - she also gave some to her husband Adam, and he ate it too.

The catechism tells us that 'the devil tempted Eve, and she gave the fruit to Adam.' Satan introduces temptation, but people are responsible for their own choices. Eve chose to believe the lie, and Adam chose to eat the fruit.

This story teaches us to be careful about temptation. Satan still tries to lead people away from God today by making sin look attractive. But we can resist temptation by remembering God's truth and asking Him for help.
prayerPoints: Ask God to help us recognize Satan's lies and temptations
Thank God for His clear commands that protect us from harm
Pray for strength to choose God's truth over Satan's lies

days.title: A Heart Full of Joy
days.lessonVerse: A joyful heart is good medicine, but a crushed spirit dries up the bones. (Proverbs 17:22)
content: Have you ever felt so happy that you couldn't stop smiling? Maybe it was your birthday, or you got to do something really fun with your family. That wonderful feeling inside is called joy, and the Bible tells us it's like good medicine for our whole body!

Our verse says that 'a joyful heart is good medicine.' Just like medicine helps us feel better when we're sick, joy helps us feel strong and healthy. When we're happy and glad, we have more energy to play, learn, and help others.

But the verse also talks about 'a crushed spirit.' This means feeling very sad or discouraged. When people feel this way for a long time, it can even affect their bodies - they might feel tired or weak more often. Sadness can drain away our strength.

Where does real joy come from? It doesn't come from having lots of toys or always getting what we want. True joy comes from knowing God loves us and that He has wonderful plans for us. Even when difficult things happen, we can still have joy because we know God is taking care of us.

The best news of all is that Jesus came to give us real joy that lasts forever! When we believe in Jesus, we know that our sins are forgiven and that we get to live with God forever in heaven. This amazing truth can fill our hearts with joy even on the hardest days.

We can share this joy with others too! When we're kind, helpful, and loving, it brings joy to other people's hearts. And when we tell others about Jesus, we're sharing the greatest source of joy in the whole world.
prayerPoints: Thank God for the joy that comes from knowing Jesus
Ask God to help us find joy even when things are difficult
Pray for opportunities to share God's joy with others

days.title: What Befell Our First Parents When They Had Sinned?

catechism.question: What befell our first parents when they had sinned?
catechism.answer: Instead of being holy and happy, they became sinful and miserable.

content: Before Adam and Eve sinned, they lived in perfect happiness. They woke up every morning with joy in their hearts, excited to spend time with God and with each other. They never felt guilty, never got sick, never worried, and never argued. Their hearts were holy - perfectly clean and good.

But the moment they chose to disobey God and eat the forbidden fruit, everything changed instantly. For the first time, they felt something terrible - guilt and shame. They suddenly felt embarrassed and tried to hide from God, something they had never wanted to do before.

Where they had once been holy, now they became sinful. Sin entered their hearts like a dark stain that couldn't be washed away. Their thoughts, feelings, and desires were no longer perfectly good. They began to want things that were wrong.

Instead of being happy, they became miserable. When God called to them in the garden, they hid among the trees because they were afraid. When God asked what they had done, Adam blamed Eve and even blamed God! Eve blamed the serpent. Their perfect relationships were broken.

This change wasn't just about feeling bad for a little while. Sin had entered their very nature, affecting everything about them. They would now grow old, get sick, and eventually die. Most importantly, they were separated from the holy God.

But even in this terrible moment, God showed His love. He promised that one day He would send Someone to defeat Satan and make things right again. That Someone was Jesus, who came to undo what Adam and Eve's sin had done.
prayerPoints: Thank God for sending Jesus to fix what sin broke
Ask God to help us understand how serious sin is
Praise God for His promise to make all things new

days.title: Our Great Deliverer
days.hymn: Rock of Ages, Cleft for Me
days.lessonVerse: The Lord is my rock and my fortress and my deliverer, my God, my rock, in whom I take refuge. (Psalm 18:2)
content: Imagine you're playing outside and suddenly a big, scary dog starts chasing you. You run as fast as you can toward your house, and just when the dog is about to catch you, your dad swoops you up in his strong arms and carries you to safety. Your dad became your deliverer - the one who rescued you from danger!

The Bible tells us that God is our Deliverer. This means He rescues us from danger and saves us when we can't save ourselves. But the danger God saves us from is much more serious than a scary dog - He delivers us from the terrible danger of sin and its punishment.

When Adam and Eve sinned in the garden, all people became trapped by sin. We couldn't free ourselves from wanting to do wrong things, and we couldn't escape the punishment that sin deserves. We were like people trapped in a burning building with no way to get out.

Our verse tells us that the Lord is our 'rock and fortress and deliverer.' A rock is strong and unmovable. A fortress is a safe place where people can hide when enemies attack. God is like both - He's strong enough to protect us and safe enough to hide in.

God showed His power as our Deliverer in the most amazing way when He sent Jesus to rescue us. Jesus came to earth, lived a perfect life, and died on the cross to take the punishment for our sins. Then He rose from the dead to show that He had defeated sin and death forever!

Now, everyone who trusts in Jesus can be delivered from sin's power and punishment. God takes us out of the kingdom of darkness and brings us into His kingdom of light. He promises us eternal life in heaven where there will be no more sin, sadness, or death.
prayerPoints: Thank God for being our strong Deliverer
Praise Jesus for rescuing us from sin and death
Ask God to help others trust in Him as their Deliverer

days.title: James Clerk Maxwell

person.name: James Clerk Maxwell
person.description: Scottish scientist who revealed God's orderly creation through studying electricity and magnetism

content: In Scotland, long ago, there lived a boy named James Clerk Maxwell who loved to ask questions about everything around him. When he was only three years old, he would point at things and ask, 'What's the go of that?' meaning 'How does that work?' His curious mind would grow up to make some of the most important scientific discoveries ever!

James was born in 1831 in Edinburgh, Scotland. His father was a lawyer who also loved science and learning. From the time James was very young, his parents encouraged him to explore and discover. They taught him that God had made an orderly, beautiful world that could be studied and understood.

At school, James was brilliant at mathematics and science. When he was only 14 years old, he wrote his first scientific paper about how to draw perfect oval shapes! Other scientists were amazed that someone so young could think of such clever ideas.

James became famous for his work with electricity and magnetism. Before his discoveries, people thought these were two completely different forces. But James proved they were actually connected as one force called 'electromagnetic.' He wrote mathematical equations that showed exactly how electricity and magnetism work together.

But James didn't just study science - he loved God deeply and believed that studying God's creation was a way to worship Him. He saw the beautiful mathematical patterns in nature as evidence of God's wisdom and design. James once said that science showed him 'the finger of God' in creation.

James also served as a Christian teacher and elder in his church. He taught Sunday school and helped other people learn about Jesus. He believed that God had given him his scientific abilities to serve others and to show how wonderful God's creation truly is.

When James died in 1879 at age 48, other scientists said he was one of the greatest thinkers who ever lived. His discoveries led to inventions like radio, television, and computers! But James would have been most happy knowing that his work helped people see God's glory in creation and that he had served his Savior faithfully.
prayerPoints: Thank God for giving people like James the ability to discover His creation
Ask God to help us see His wisdom and design in the world around us
Pray that we would use whatever gifts God gives us to serve Him
